description:
Amycolatopsis lurida is a species of actinobacteria that belongs to the genus Amycolatopsis. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium.

The cells of Amycolatopsis lurida are typically rod-shaped and can form branching filaments. The colony morphology on agar plates is usually smooth, circular, and a distinctive reddish-brown or lurid color, which is the origin of the species name "lurida."

This bacterium is known to be a producer of secondary metabolites, including antibiotics and other bioactive compounds. Amycolatopsis lurida has been isolated from various environmental sources, such as soil and plant materials.

Phylogenetically, Amycolatopsis lurida is closely related to other species within the Amycolatopsis genus, which are known for their ability to produce a wide range of industrially and medically important compounds. The genome of Amycolatopsis lurida has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential for natural product biosynthesis.

Overall, Amycolatopsis lurida is an actinobacterial species of interest due to its ability to produce secondary metabolites and its potential applications in biotechnology and natural product discovery.
